awd_titl_txt: Factors Underlying the Rise of Complex Societies
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. David Chicoine, of Louisiana State University, in collaboration with Dr. George Lau from the University of East Anglia, will undertake archaeological field research to document and understand the rise of divine lordships in ancient Peru. The project has significant intellectual merit and broad societal impact as it will contribute to our knowledge about the diversity in forms of rulership and authority through time and space. One of the leading topics in archaeology today is social complexity, or the study of variability in the forms of organization and authority in large-scale political systems. The project enriches this crucial field of study by investigating the emergence of divine rulership, in which certain humans come to be treated as god-like supernaturals, and their authority and being are seen as divine. The beginnings of this distinctive kind of political system, which has been common and continues today in world contexts, are not well understood archaeologically, especially for the Central Andes, one of the heartlands of Pre-Columbian civilization. The research project will bring insights into this important topic by uncovering primary archaeological evidence to monitor changes over time in leadership strategies and ways that rulers justified their authority, including claiming special connections with landscapes, ancestors, and supernatural beings.

Three field seasons and detailed post-excavation studies will investigate the ancient political centers of Cerro San Isidro (Moro region, Nepena Valley) and Pashash (Pallasca region), and their surrounding hinterlands in the northern Ancash Department, Peru. Survey of regional settlement patterns, as well as excavation data from elite architecture, material culture, and funerary activities will allow comparison of pivotal cultural transformations leading to lordships. Excavations within walled house compounds and plaza areas will help to distinguish high-status and commoner activities. Analysis of skeletal remains from nearby tombs will help to characterize the individuals associated with the compounds. Studies of artifacts and coeval visual arts will offer insights into the role of ancestors in local ritual practices and the exercise of authority. Researching these data comparatively will illuminate how and when major forms of divine lordships took root in ancient Peru. Such polities were especially prominent in the study region where ancient lords, according to ethnohistorical chronicles, levied labor obligations from each household to coordinate collective tasks (irrigation, ritual, war), while having cosmological and moral duties to ensure order and the people's well-being. A leader's claim to legitimacy was pinned to his bloodline and link to an exalted founding ancestor. This kind of Andean social organization has three corollaries with key project implications: (1) a tendency, over time, for more groups to feature ancestors at the apex of their social hierarchy, (2) esteemed leaders come to share in the status of divinities, and (3) a critical innovation is the integration of the esteemed dead into the political life of nobles as they become institutionalized as regular actors in the socio-political system. The project will build fruitful links with local institutions (schools, museums) and hence add value to the management of Pre-Columbian cultural heritage.

This award is made possible under the SBE-UKRI lead agency activity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project leverages archaeological data to examine the factors underlying social complexity in the Andean region of South America. Despite the excellent preservation and richness of Peru's archaeology, major gaps exist in the study of its ancient political systems. This project fills this gap by looking at the rise of complex societies and, specifically, the early record of divine lordships in northern Peru, which took hold following the demise of the Chavin culture around the middle of the first millennium BC. Many later Andean states saw their rulers as ancestralized, sacred beings, but the development of such arrangements remains unclear. Shedding light on such political developments is of great relevance to global human concerns including the preponderant role of religion and sacralized leaders in the perpetuation of state-level political arrangements.

The project met its objectives and generated primary archaeological data to analyze social complexity through several lenses including the intensification of resource control, material culture, warrior leadership, factional competition, the rise of ancestor veneration practices, and the construction of sacred landscapes. Fieldwork focused field operations in the middle Nepena Valley, a region of northern Peru where the PI has carried out research for the last 25 years. In accordance with Peruvian regulations, the PI co-directed 22 weeks of fieldwork at the ancient hilltop settlement of Cerro San Isidro, located in the Moro region of the middle Nepena (Province of Santa, Department of Ancash). The team integrated local archaeologists and field/lab assistants, as well as provided capacity training to Peruvian and US students.

In the field, the project combined survey (pedestrian using Global Positioning System, drone, Ground Penetrating Radar) and excavation methods that yielded spatial, material, and chronological information on the organization and sequence of the site's ancient occupation. Radiocarbon measurements from stratified contexts indicate that Cerro San Isidro was intensively occupied and modified by humans between 800 BC and AD 1500. One major observation is that the site once extended well beyond its modern limits, thus bolstering its political importance as a major urban-like population center in the past.

Excavations sampled four terraces or platforms through block excavations, as well as eight smaller test units for more than 500 square meters. All materials were screened, cleaned, inventoried, and stored according to Peruvian regulations. Following the guidelines from Peru's Ministerio de Cultura, all units were backfilled to preserve the integrity of the archaeological contexts for future archaeological and conservation efforts.

Field operations were reported to Peruvian authorities in a timely manner and reports stored on LSU's Digital Commons online repository. Excavations yielded rich collections from stratified contexts spanning the whole duration of the site’s occupation. Preliminary results have already been disseminated through technical reports, publications, public lectures, and conference presentations while more detailed analyses are ongoing. Analytical procedures include a comprehensive inventory and description of the findings, selective visual records (photographs and drawings), stylistic and morphometric descriptions of the ceramic vessel fragments, the taxonomic classification of the faunal and floral assemblages, radiocarbon dating, and the geochemical and petrographic characterization of pottery fragments. Results of these analyses will lead to numerous high-quality publications exploring the development of social complexity and its anthropological significance to understand divine rulership through time and space.

The project generated life-changing research opportunities for several students, including graduate students at LSU and elsewhere, many of whom came from historically underrepresented groups. Data from Cerro San Isidro have so far served as the basis of four MA theses and one doctoral dissertation. These research initiatives explore pottery making and material culture, zooarchaeology and human-animal relations, patterns of residential living, mortuary practices, and the spatial and urban-like dimensions of the ancient settlement of Cerro San Isidro, respectively.

In addition to training local and US archaeologists and contributing to capacity building in Peru, the project actively collaborated with community organizations in Moro to develop outreach and educational activities. In consultation with local community leaders including elected officials, schoolteachers, museum curators, professional archaeologists, landowners, and others, the project contributed to raising awareness about archaeology and prehistory, educating non-specialists, protecting cultural heritage, and stimulating an equitable and fair economic development. In Moro, the project partnered with the Peruvian non-profit organizations Asociacion Caminemos Unidos (ACU) and its Museo Arqueologico de las Tecnologias Andinas in developing educational workshops and documentary videos (disseminated through the ACU Facebook platform). Still in Moro, the PI and his team also delivered a series of classes at the local elementary school (Colegio Santo Domingo de Moro).
